Name: Skiddaw
Observations: ground 30m E at NY 26073 29083 is of similar height
Description: Standing as the fourth highest peak in the Lake District
column22: Skiddaw dominates the northern skyline of Keswick with its distinctive smooth
column23: grassy slopes. The mountain offers a relatively straightforward ascent via the well-trodden tourist path from Keswick
column24: making it popular despite its considerable height. From its summit
column25: visitors enjoy panoramic views across the northern lakes
column27: and on clear days as far as Scotland and the Isle of Man. Skiddaw is part of the Skiddaw Group of slate
column29: making it among the oldest rock formations in the Lake District. The upper slopes feature alpine-type vegetation adapted to the harsh conditions
column30: while the lower slopes are home to heather moorland and woodland.

Name: Blencathra
Observations: ground 30m W at NY 32314 27710 may be of similar height
Description: Often called Saddleback due to its distinctive shape
column22: Blencathra offers some of the most exciting ridge walking in the Lake District
column23: including the famous Sharp Edge scramble for experienced hikers. The fell consists of six separate fell tops and provides diverse routes of ascent ranging from gentle walks to challenging scrambles. From its summit
column24: climbers are rewarded with expansive views over the Solway Firth
column26: and much of the Lake District. Blencathra's geological makeup consists primarily of Skiddaw slate
column27: and the mountain has been a backdrop for local sheep farming for centuries. The fell's slopes support resilient upland vegetation and provide habitat for birds of prey and mountain wildlife.

Name: Skiddaw Little Man
Description: Skiddaw Little Man stands as a distinctive peak on the southern shoulder of its parent mountain
column23: creating an appealing profile when viewed from Keswick. Though sometimes considered merely a subsidiary summit
column24: this fell has earned its place as a Wainwright in its own right due to its distinct character and the fine views it offers. The most popular ascent route is via the well-maintained path from Keswick that continues on to Skiddaw
column25: making it a frequent stopping point for those tackling the larger mountain. From its summit
column26: walkers enjoy spectacular views of Derwentwater
column28: and the surrounding northern fells. The exposed position means the peak often experiences strong winds
column29: but the clearly defined path makes it accessible for moderately experienced hikers.

Name: Carl Side
column22: grassy dome on the northwestern shoulder of Skiddaw
column23: offering a gentler alternative route to the summit of its parent mountain. The fell is characterized by its rounded profile and extensive grassy slopes
column24: which contrast with the more rugged terrain found elsewhere in the Lake District. From its summit
column25: marked by a small pile of stones
column26: hikers can enjoy excellent views of Bassenthwaite Lake and the Solway Firth to the north and west. The most popular ascent route is from the Dodd Wood car park
column27: which provides a steady climb through woodland before emerging onto open fellside. Carl Side serves as an important link in the horseshoe walk that takes in Skiddaw

Name: Long Side
Observations: ground 35m W at NY 24844 28447 is of similar height
Description: Long Side extends westward from Carl Side as part of the northern ridge descending from Skiddaw
column22: forming a prominent profile when viewed from Bassenthwaite Lake. The fell features a distinctive
column23: elongated summit ridge that gives it its name
column24: with steep northern slopes dropping dramatically toward Southerndale. Hikers typically reach Long Side as part of the Skiddaw horseshoe walk
column25: enjoying particularly fine views across Bassenthwaite Lake and toward the Solway Coast. The summit
column27: sits at the eastern end of the ridge and provides a sense of isolation despite its proximity to more popular fells. The grassy terrain offers straightforward walking
column28: making it accessible to moderately experienced hikers
column29: though the ridge can be exposed during adverse weather.

Name: Lonscale Fell
Feature: no feature: ground 25m S of cairn
Description: Lonscale Fell forms the southeastern spur of the Skiddaw massif
column22: distinguished by its dramatic eastern face where steep slopes drop sharply toward the Glenderaterra Valley. The fell offers a variety of ascent routes
column23: with the most popular being from Keswick via the well-maintained bridleway known as Gale Road
column24: or from the Blencathra Centre along the old railway line. Despite being somewhat overshadowed by its more famous neighbors
column25: Lonscale Fell rewards visitors with extensive views toward Derwentwater and the central fells from its gently rounded summit. The western slopes feature extensive grassy terrain
column26: while the eastern crags provide a more challenging aspect that appeals to scramblers and rock climbers. Wildlife enthusiasts may spot ravens and peregrine falcons soaring around the eastern crags

Name: Knott
Description: Knott stands as one of the more remote fells in the Northern Lake District
column23: grassy dome and extensive summit plateau. Despite being the second highest peak in the Northern Fells after Skiddaw
column24: it remains relatively quiet due to its distance from popular starting points and the lack of dramatic features that attract casual visitors. The fell offers a sense of solitude and wilderness
column25: with the most common approaches being from Mosedale or via the connecting ridge from Great Calva. From its summit cairn
column26: hikers enjoy panoramic views across the Northern Fells
column27: with particularly good vistas toward the Caldbeck Fells and the Border hills. The extensive grassy terrain supports grazing for Herdwick sheep
column28: and careful observers may spot mountain hares which inhabit the higher slopes. The flat summit area can become boggy after rain
column29: typical of many of the Northern Fells.

Name: Bowscale Fell
Description: Bowscale Fell rises as a rounded dome to the east of the Caldew valley
column22: forming part of the eastern boundary of the Northern Fells. The mountain is best known for Bowscale Tarn
column23: a small corrie lake nestled on its northern flank
column24: which legend claims is home to immortal fish. Walkers typically approach from the village of Mungrisdale to the east or from the Caldew valley to the west
column25: with the latter route passing through the remote and picturesque Mosedale. From the summit
column26: marked by a stone shelter and nearby cairn
column27: hikers enjoy extensive views eastward toward the Pennines and Cross Fell
column28: as well as westward to Blencathra and the Northern Fells. The broad
column29: grassy slopes support typical upland vegetation and provide grazing for Herdwick sheep
column30: with occasional sightings of red deer in the quieter areas. The ridge connecting to Bannerdale Crags offers a pleasant high-level traverse with minimal height loss.

Name: Ullock Pike
Description: Ullock Pike presents one of the most striking profiles in the Northern Fells
column22: forming the southern end of the elegant ridge that extends northwest from Skiddaw. The fell's shapely pyramid appears particularly impressive when viewed from Bassenthwaite Lake
column23: where it stands as a perfect counterpoint to the bulk of Skiddaw behind. Most walkers ascend from the Ravenstone Hotel or Dodd Wood
column24: tackling a steep but rewarding climb up the narrow
column26: marked by a small rocky outcrop
column27: offers spectacular views over Bassenthwaite Lake and toward the Solway Firth. Ullock Pike forms part of a popular horseshoe walk with Long Side and Carl Side
column28: eventually leading to Skiddaw itself. The western slopes drop steeply into Southerndale
column29: creating dramatic terrain that contrasts with the gentler eastern aspects that connect to Carlside.
